M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex County Superior Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Middlesex County.

Sheehan v. Roche Brothers Supermarkets,.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Brothers Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 785-86 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Brothers Supermarkets,.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff and other invitees to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect invitees from hazardous conditions of which it knew or should have known.
Sheehan v. Roche Brothers Supermarkets,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Brothers Supermarkets,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes that a store owner owes invitees a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from hazardous conditions the owner knows or should know about. The court quotes Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and its own precedent (Mounsey, Barry, Gilhooley, Gallagher) to reaffirm this traditional duty, then modifies only how notice may be established via the mode-of-operation approach. Thus, the case supports the general duty proposition stated.
Sheehan v. Roche Brothers Supermarkets,.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). … This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition.”

O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (.support_reasoning: The case does not support the claimed proposition about breach being a direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Instead, the court holds that the defendants owed no duty at all because the danger of diving into the shallow end was open and obvious, and therefore they cannot be liable. Causation is not the basis of the decision; the opinion resolves the case entirely on the absence of duty and thus negates any finding of proximate cause flowing from a breach.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury.” … “We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant knew or should have known about the dangerous condition of the spilled milk given the fact that its employee admitted to observing the spill but took no action to address it.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s knowledge of a spill where an employee observed spilled milk and failed to act. Papadopoulos v. Target concerns premises liability for slip-and-fall on snow/ice in a parking lot and the abolition of the natural/unnatural accumulation rule; it does not involve indoor spills, employee observations of a spill, or constructive/actual notice via an employee’s admission. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific knowledge-based proposition about spilled milk.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782-784 (2007) …”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Defendant’s negligence caused Plaintiff to sustain foreseeable injuries, consistent with longstanding Massachusetts tort principles.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies Massachusetts negligence principles of duty, foreseeability, and causation to conclude that a landowner can be liable where their negligent conduct creates a foreseeable risk of physical harm, even if the danger is open and obvious. The court emphasizes that the defendants intentionally created and maintained a trampoline-pool setup knowing it was dangerous and that users would likely attempt exactly the kind of conduct that caused plaintiff’s injuries, and it reiterates that precise manner of injury need not be foreseen so long as some such injury is foreseeable. This aligns with the claimed proposition that a defendant’s negligence can cause a plaintiff’s foreseeable injuries under longstanding Massachusetts tort law.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool…for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool. He knew that the pool warned against jumping of any kind, and he knew that the setup was dangerous but proceeded…because he thought it would be ‘fun.’ … ‘[T]o be held liable the defendant need not have foreseen the precise manner in which the injuries occurred.’ … Given the shallow depth of the water, there was no reliably safe way to propel oneself from the trampoline into the pool. The defendants knew that it was unsafe to do so and, therefore, could or should have anticipated injuries resulting from this activity.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, business owners are responsible for injuries caused by unsafe conditions on their premises of which they knew or should have known.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the duty of one who controls business premises: to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe or warn of dangers that are not likely to be known to patrons and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. It further explains that liability can be based on the defendant having caused the condition, having actual knowledge, or the condition existing long enough that the defendant should have known of it. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts business owners are responsible for injuries from unsafe conditions they knew or should have known about.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable precautions reflects actionable negligence under Massachusetts law.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on causation, not on whether the defendants’ failure to take reasonable precautions constitutes actionable negligence. The dissent actually assumes for argument’s sake that there was negligence (e.g., inadequate locking system, insufficient guards) but concludes that plaintiff failed to prove proximate cause and that defendants were entitled to directed verdicts. Thus, this portion of Mullins does not stand as authority that failure to take reasonable precautions is actionable negligence under Massachusetts law; it argues the opposite result on causation grounds.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence, but I do not agree that the jury could have found that entry into the room was gained by disengaging a lock. … In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: By failing to address a known safety hazard, Defendant created an unreasonable risk of harm to its customers, including Plaintiff.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The concurrence states that the risk of injury from negligent operation of another vehicle at a self-service station is inherent and obvious, and explicitly concludes that there is no duty to warn of such a danger. The court agreed there was no jury question on Arco’s alleged failure to warn. This undercuts, rather than supports, the proposition that failing to address a known safety hazard created an unreasonable risk of harm to customers in this context.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The question is whether, as a matter of law, Arco’s failure to erect a sign warning customers to be on guard against other vehicles did not unreasonably increase the risk of injury caused by the improper operation of other vehicles on the premises. I agree with the court that the evidence did not present a jury question. … In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."
